yields on long-term bonds have fallen as Federal Reserve has increased interest rates; such occurrence is atypical because investors who take on additional risk by investing in long-term bonds are typically paid more to do so than those who have taken on less risk by investing in shorter-term issues; behind oddity is Treasury Department's plan to reduce nation's debt; perception that there is going to be shortage of long-term US Treasuries has brought these investors into market with vengeance, causing yields on long-term bonds to plunge; what worries some bond market participants is that this plunge in yields will blunt impact that Fed's interest rate increases will have on economy; but with long-term rates so low, shrewd borrowers who might typically have tapped short-term market for capital will simply issue long-term debt; easy access to cheap, long-term debt will help to keep econony hot, while Fed wants it to cool (M)")('2000020', 'Anthony Tommasini reviews recital by soprano Norah Amsellem at Weill Recital Hall (S)')('2000020', "Econoists say Canada's economy is likely to show 4 perent expansion for 1999; Hodgson was not focus of investigation to uncover kickback schemes and other business crimes in aerospace industry, nor was he ever charged with any crime; though partners have failed in their legal efforts to be compensated for their claimed losses, case has resulted in court opinion that may increase chances that innocent third parties injured in sting operations can collect for damages against law enforcement agents; three-judge panel of US Appeals Court ruled last fall that law enforcement officers can be held liable if with deliberate indifference they harm 'an innocent nontarget'; decision is particularly relevant for investigations of white-collar, or business, crimes; Justice Department official says that internal probe of sting operation has so far found no indication of any violation of department guidelines; FBI, to convince business partners that FBI agent John Clifford (real name is James H Francis) and other undercover agents were legitimate, enlisted help of companies including Dun & Bradstreet and NationsBank (now merged into Bank of America); though Hodgson, Satterwhite and their two companies were never charged with any crime, Brown eventually was; after vague instruction from Clifford to associate of Brown, Brown ended up in Hobby Airport Hilton Hotel in Houston passing 'a sealed envelope containing entertainment funds' to Army procurement officer; FBI was secretly taping exchange; case of offering $500 bribe to public official ended in mistrial after jury deadlocked, with US attorney's office declining to retry it; photos (M)")('2000020', 'Richard Bernstein reviews Memories of a Pure Spring, novel by Duong Thu Huong;
